title: Domain 3.4: Given a scenario, implement IPv4 and IPv6 network services.

ğŸ–§ DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol)

Reservations

DHCP reservations ensure that a specific device always gets the same IP address from the DHCP server based on its MAC address.

Common use: Assigning static IPs to devices like printers, servers, and network equipment without manually configuring them.

Scope

The DHCP scope defines the range of IP addresses that can be assigned to devices within a network.

Common use: Limits the pool of available IP addresses based on the size of the network.

Lease Time

Lease time specifies how long a device can use an assigned IP address before it must renew the lease.

Common use: Typically set to a few hours or days depending on network needs.

Options

DHCP options allow additional settings to be provided to devices during IP assignment, such as DNS servers or default gateways.

Common use: Configure network devices with necessary settings (e.g., DNS servers).

Relay/IP Helper

A relay agent forwards DHCP requests between clients and servers, especially when the client is on a different subnet.

Common use: Used in larger networks where clients are located in different subnets than the DHCP server.

Exclusions

Exclusions define IP addresses within the scope that should not be assigned to devices. This is often used for IP addresses that need to be manually assigned.

Common use: Prevent the DHCP server from assigning IPs to devices that should have static IPs.

ğŸŒ Stateless Address Autoconfiguration (SLAAC)

SLAAC allows a device to automatically configure its own IPv6 address without the need for a DHCP server. The device uses information from the local network (router advertisements) to generate its own address.

Common use: Devices in IPv6 networks use SLAAC for automatic addressing in the absence of a DHCP server.

â° Time Protocols

â±ï¸ NTP (Network Time Protocol)

NTP is a protocol used to synchronize the clocks of devices over a network to ensure accurate timekeeping. It uses a client-server model, where the client requests time from a server.

Common use: Ensures that all devices in a network have the same time for logging and timestamping activities.

ğŸ•’ Precision Time Protocol (PTP)

PTP is a more precise version of NTP, designed for applications that require very accurate time synchronization, often down to the nanosecond.

Common use: Used in high-precision environments like financial networks, industrial automation, and telecommunications.

ğŸ›¡ï¸ Network Time Security (NTS)

NTS enhances NTP by adding encryption and authentication to prevent tampering with time synchronization. This ensures that time data cannot be maliciously altered.

Common use: Used in environments where security is critical and time accuracy must be maintained without interference.

ğŸŒ DNS (Domain Name System)

DNS is the service that translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses that machines use to communicate.

ğŸ” DNSSEC

DNSSEC adds security to DNS by allowing DNS responses to be verified for authenticity, helping to prevent attacks like cache poisoning.

ğŸ”’ DoH and DoT

DoH and DoT encrypt DNS queries, making them more secure by preventing third parties from intercepting or modifying them.

ğŸ“ Hosts File

The hosts file is a local text file used by operating systems to map hostnames to IP addresses. It overrides DNS and is useful for testing or internal mappings.

Common use: Manually setting up domain mappings before DNS propagation or for testing purposes.
